questions.text: A 35-year-old lady presents with pulmonary TB is started on anti-tubercular therapy. What is the rationale for administering multi-drug therapy to her?

choices.text: To prevent toxin release from the organism

questions.solution:
The reason for administering multi-drug therapy in tuberculosis is to prevent the development of resistance.

Resistance to individual drugs in Mycobacterium tuberculosis occurs by spontaneous point mutations that occur at a low but predictable rate (10-7 to 10-10 ). Development of this drug resistance is almost invariably the result of monotherapy, i.e., the failure of the health care provider to prescribe at least 2 drugs to which the tubercle bacilli are susceptible. Hence, multi-drug therapy is recommended for the treatment of tuberculosis.

questions.text: Which is the most effective drug against extracellular mycobacteria?
questions.solution:
The most effective drug against extracellular mycobacteria is Rifampicin. 

Option A: Isoniazid and Rifampicin act against both intracellular and extracellular mycobacterium. But, Rifampicin inhibits the extracellular mycobacteria at much lower drug concentrations than isoniazid.

Option B: Pyrazinamide acts only against intracellular mycobacterium.

Option C: Ethambutol acts against only extracellular mycobacteria but is not as effective as rifampicin. It is a bacteriostatic drug. Fast-multiplying bacteria are highly susceptible to its action. 

Note: Streptomycin is primarily active against only the extracellular tubercle bacilli as its penetration into the cells is very poor.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and was started on first-line antitubercular drugs. Which of the following drug acts by inhibiting the synthesis of the marked layer shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Isoniazid is the first-line antitubercular drug that acts by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acid.

Isoniazid is a first-line bactericidal drug that is used for the treatment of tuberculosis. This drug enters bacilli by passive diffusion. It then gets activated to its toxic form by the enzyme catalase-peroxidase(the enzyme encoded by the Kat gene).

Normally, InhA and KasA are involved in the synthesis of mycolic acid. Upon activation, the reactive metabolite of isoniazid forms complexes with NAD that inhibit InhA and KasA. Hence, isoniazid inhibits the production of mycolic acid.

The reactive isoniazid metabolite also forms complexes with NADP. This complex inhibits mycobacterial dihydrofolate reductase which results in the interruption of DNA synthesis.

Side effects of isoniazid include:

  • Peripheral neuritis due to interference with the production of active coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate from pyridoxine. Therefore, pyridoxine 10mg/day (vitamin B6) is given prophylactically along with isoniazid to prevent neurotoxicity.
  • Hepatitis - isoniazid must be stopped at the first sign of hepatotoxicity.
  • Rashes
  • Anaemia
  • Arthralgia

Toxicity of isoniazid results in metabolic acidosis, seizures, and coma.

Other options:

Option B: Rifampin acts by binding to DNA-dependent RNA polymerase to form a stable drug-enzyme complex. This complex suppresses RNA synthesis. Side effects of rifampin are hepatitis, flu-like illness, orange-red colored urine, and body secretions.

 Option C: Pyrazinamide is a prodrug, it is converted into an active metabolite pyrazinoic acid which makes the intracellular environment acidic and collapses the transmembrane proton motive force, thereby killing the bacteria. Side effects include hyperuricemia and hepatotoxicity. 

Option D: Ethambutol inhibits arabinose transferase III, thereby decreasing arabinogalactan biosynthesis. This results in disruption in mycobacterial cell wall synthesis. Optic neuritis is an important side effect of ethambutol. It results in decreased visual acuity and loss of red-green discrimination.

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

questions.text: A study was conducted to genotype NAT2 gene polymorphisms in patients receiving ATT. Among the 300 patients genotyped, 200 were slow acetylators (group A), 70 were intermediate (group B) and 30 were fast acetylators (group C). Patients in group A are prone to develop which of the following?
questions.solution:
Isoniazid, a key agent in the ATT, is metabolized primarily through N-acetylation by the genetically polymorphic N-acetyltransferase-2 (NAT2) enzyme. Slow acetylators (group A) of isoniazid are prone to develop peripheral neuropathy.

The rate of metabolism of isoniazid is determined by the genetic polymorphism of NAT2 enzyme and classified broadly into two groups - slow and fast acetylators.

In slow acetylators, the drug accumulates due to slow metabolism resulting in an increased risk of side effects, and hence they should undergo periodic monitoring. Peripheral neuropathy is a more frequent side effect of INH when compared to hepatotoxicity.

Fast acetylators metabolize the drug rapidly and show less response to standard doses and the therapy may be less effective.

questions.text: Line probe assay done on sputum sample of a patient with TB revealed over-expression of InhA gene. This can lead to cross-resistance of isoniazid with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Over-expression of the gene for InhA leads to cross-resistance of isoniazid (INH) with ethionamide. 

Mechanisms of INH resistance
Mutation of KatG 
  • most common mechanism
  • confers a high level of resistance
Overexpression of InhA
  • confers a low level of resistance 
  • cross-resistance with ethionamide
Overexpression of ahpC
  • increases the bacterial survival under oxidative stress
Induction of efflux pumps
  • cross-resistance with ethambutol

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy was brought to the ER with recurrent seizures. His mother informs you that he is receiving isoniazid prophylaxis as she was diagnosed with TB during pregnancy. ABG revealed a high anion gap metabolic acidosis. What would be the mainstay of treatment?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of isoniazid overdose for which the mainstay of treatment is intravenous pyridoxine.

Isoniazid overdose results in decreased pyridoxine availability to neurons. This decreases the levels of GABA, which in turn lowers the seizure threshold. Benzodiazepines can be used to control seizures.

Prolonged treatment with isoniazid leads to the deficiency of pyridoxine which can lead to peripheral neuropathy and other neurological manifestations like ataxia, paresthesia, and numbness.

Clinical triad of isoniazid overdose:

  • Seizures refractory to treatment with phenytoin and barbiturates
  • High anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) resistant to treatment with sodium bicarbonate
  • Coma

questions.text: A 30-year-old man undergoing treatment for TB visits your OPD for follow-up. His wife states that recently he is forgetting the names of his colleagues and neighbors, but later recollects them correctly. Which drug is implicated to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Isoniazid is the antitubercular drug that is implicated in the causation of transient memory loss.

Neurological toxicities like peripheral neuropathy, optic neuritis, and seizures can occur with isoniazid therapy. It is also associated with abnormalities like:

  • Euphoria
  • Transient memory loss
  • Separation of ideas and reality
  • Loss of self-control
  • Florid psychosis

Pyridoxine therapy can prevent and reverse most of the neurological toxicity and mental abnormalities.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman, on anti-tubercular therapy, presented with pain in the right hand and shoulder for the past 1 month. On physical examination, her wrist was swollen and her shoulder was extremely painful with a limited range of motion. Which drug is most likely associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is suggestive of shoulder-hand syndrome which is associated with the use of isoniazid.

This syndrome is characterized by painful arthropathy in the upper extremity joints. It can also present as generalized arthropathy.

Other drugs that can cause shoulder-hand syndrome are phenobarbitone and phenytoin.

questions.text: Before initiating treatment for a sputum-positive TB patient, the physician orders for Cartridge Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test in order to test for drug resistance. Which anti-tubercular drug resistance is he checking for?
questions.solution:
The Cartridge Based-Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT) is a molecular test for tuberculosis that detects the DNA of tubercle bacilli within 2 hours and mutations in the rpoB gene responsible for rifampicin resistance.

questions.text: Which of the following rifamycin drugs would you advise a patient to take on an empty stomach?
questions.solution:
Rifampicin should be advised to be taken on an empty stomach because food decreases its absorption. 

Rifabutin absorption is not altered by food.

Rifapentine absorption is enhanced by fatty food and hence it is recommended to be taken with food.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient on ART with zidovudine, lamivudine, and indinavir develops pulmonary tuberculosis. Which of the following anti-tubercular drugs should be avoided in him?
questions.solution:
Rifampicin should be avoided as it is a potent inducer of CYP enzymes including CYPs 1A2, 3A4, 2C9, and 2C19, which in turn can induce the metabolism of indinavir and results in therapeutic failure of ART.

Rifabutin causes the least induction of cytochrome enzymes and is therefore preferred in HIV patients who are on protease inhibitors/NNRTIs.

Cytochrome enzyme-inducing potency of rifamycins is: rifampicin > rifapentine > rifabutin.

  • Azole antifungals

questions.text: Which of the following rifamycins is not used for mycobacterial infections?
questions.solution:
Rifaximin is not used for mycobacterial infections. It is a synthetic rifamycin that is poorly absorbed from the GIT and is indicated in the management of GI conditions like: 

  • Traveler’s diarrhea
  • Irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhea
  • Hepatic encephalopathy

Rifamycins indicated in mycobacterial infections are rifampicin, rifapentine, and rifabutin.

questions.text: A Gene Xpert test was conducted on the sputum sample of a patient with suspected TB. The results were positive and showed resistance to rifampicin. What is the primary mechanism of resistance against this drug?
questions.solution:
Rifampicin resistance is primarily due to alteration in the target enzyme. 

Rifampicin acts by binding to the β subunit of DNA-dependent RNA polymerase (rpoB) and inhibits chain formation in RNA synthesis. Rifampicin is a potent inducer of cytochrome enzymes CYP3A4, CYP1A2, CYP2C9, and CYP2C19. Alteration of the target enzyme (rpoB) by a mutation in the gene coding for rpoB is the primary mechanism of resistance to rifampicin. Gene Xpert identifies mutations in the rpoB gene to detect rifampicin resistance.

Efflux pump induction has also been demonstrated as a mechanism of rifampicin resistance.

questions.text:
In which of the following conditions can rifampicin be used?
  1. Prophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis
  2. Treatment of brucellosis
  3. Eradication of staphylococcal nasal carrier state
  4. Treatment of pleuropulmonary nocardiosis
  5. Treatment of paucibacillary leprosy
questions.solution:
Besides its anti-tubercular action, rifampicin also has certain non-tubercular uses which include:

  • Prophylaxis of meningococcal and H. influenzae meningitis
  • Treatment of MRSA, diphtheroid, and legionella infections 
  • Eradication of staphylococcal nasal carrier state in patients with chronic furunculosis
  • A combination of doxycycline and rifampicin is used as the first-line therapy for brucellosis
  • A part of the WHO regimen for standard therapy of both paucibacillary and multibacillary leprosy

Rifampicin is not used in the treatment of Nocardia species. Cotrimoxazole is considered the drug of choice for pleuropulmonary nocardiosis.

questions.text: You are prescribing first-line anti-tubercular therapy to a patient newly diagnosed with TB. Which of the following is incorrect about his therapy?

choices.text: Red green color impairment is an early sign of ethambutol induced optic neuritis
Flu-like syndrome is usually seen if rifampicin is taken on a daily basis
Hyperuricemia is a recognised side effect of pyrazinamide

questions.solution:
Flu-like syndrome is usually seen when rifampicin is administered less than twice weekly (high dose) and it is uncommon when administered daily (lower dose).

Flu-like syndrome, characterized by fevers, chills, malaise, and arthralgia is a known dose-dependent adverse effect of rifampicin therapy and tends to occur late into the patient's treatment course. It resolves with either discontinuation of rifampin or switching to a daily-dose regimen. It can often be confused with occult infections or treatment failure. 

Options A and B: Red-green colour impairment is one of the early signs of ethambutol-induced optic neuritis. Ethambutol is primarily excreted unchanged by kidneys and accumulation occurs in renal failure. Ethambutol does not undergo hepatic metabolism and can be safely prescribed for the treatment of TB in patients with hepatitis.

Option D: Pyrazinamide interferes with urate excretion and can result in hyperuricemia.

questions.text: A young woman undergoing treatment for tuberculosis visits your OPD for a routine checkup. She informs you that recently she has noticed an orange-colored discoloration of her contact lenses. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Rifampicin is the drug most likely to cause orange-colored discoloration of contact lenses in this case.

Drugs like rifampicin and rifabutin are known to cause reddish-orange discoloration of the skin, urine, feces, saliva, sweat, and tears (which can stain the patient's contact lenses).

questions.text: You are planning to start treatment in a middle-aged man diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis. He has a history of chronic kidney disease and his current creatinine clearance is 25 mL/min. Which of the following drugs is least likely to require dose modification?
questions.solution:
Rifampicin is the least likely drug to require dose modification in renal failure patients as it is metabolized in the liver and primarily excreted in bile. 

In patients with renal failure, the half-life of isoniazid will be prolonged, but its adverse effects are not significantly increased. Hence dose modification is not usually done for isoniazid in clinical practice as a reduction in dose may render the regimen ineffective and increase the chances of resistance.

Ethambutol and streptomycin are primarily excreted unchanged through the renal system and need dose modification in renal failure.

This is a controversial question. Upon thorough review, we found that both rifampicin and isoniazid do not require dose adjustment. However, rifampicin would be the single best answer as it has a safer profile in CKD patients.

questions.text: Pseudojaundice is an adverse effect of which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Pseudojaundice is an adverse effect of rifabutin. It resolves on discontinuation of the drug.

Unique adverse effects of rifabutin are:

  • Polymyalgia/arthralgia
  • Pseudojaundice
  • Anterior uveitis

questions.text: Mycobacterium tuberculosis nicotinamidase is involved in the activation of which of the following antitubercular drug?
questions.solution:
Mycobacterium tuberculosis nicotinamidase is involved in the activation of pyrazinamide.

Nicotinamidase which is produced by M. tuberculosis is also called pyrazinamidase. It is encoded by the pncA gene and its mutations are associated with pyrazinamide resistance. It converts pyrazinamide to active pyrazinoic acid.

Pyrazinoic acid has the following actions:

  • Inhibition of fatty acid synthetase type 1 leads to interference in mycolic acid synthesis
  • Reduction of intracellular pH
  • Disruption of membrane transport

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man on treatment for TB presents with complaints of severe pain and swelling in his left great toe since today morning, as shown in the image below. Which of the following drugs is most likely to cause this?
  1. Rifampicin
  2. Pyrazinamide
  3. Isoniazid
  4. Ethambutol
  5. Streptomycin
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and findings of first metatarsophalangeal joint swelling are suggestive of an acute episode of gout. Antitubercular drugs that are most likely to cause hyperuricemia and precipitate gout are pyrazinamide and ethambutol.

Both pyrazinamide and ethambutol inhibit uric acid excretion in the kidney causing hyperuricemia.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman receiving treatment for TB presents to your OPD with complaints of blurry vision and pain on movement of the left eye for the past 2 days. Examination showed Marcus Gunn pupil. Which anti-tubercular drug is most likely associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features along with Marcus Gunn pupil are suggestive of optic neuritis, which is a dose-dependent adverse effect associated with ethambutol.

Optic neuritis resulting in decreased visual acuity and loss of red-green discrimination is the most serious adverse effect of ethambutol. It can be unilateral or bilateral and usually recovers when the drug is stopped.

Tests of visual acuity and red-green discrimination before the start of therapy and periodically thereafter are recommended.
